content.content:
1→--- 2→layout: page 3→title: About 4→permalink: /about/ 5→--- 6→This is Kyle Zhao(赵柯宇), I'm a software engineer at [tencent](https://tencent.com) on [Git](https://github.com/git/git) and Java Web. 7→ 8→# * Work Experience 9→## *App Development* 10→
Tencent          2020.06 ~ now
11→SCM, Infra, Web, Git 12→ 13→
14→ 15→## *Intern* 16→
Zoom Video Communications, Inc   2019.03 ~ 2019.06
17→VOIP, Web 18→ 19→
20→ 21→# * Open Source 22→### Some of My Contribution 23→#### [Git](https://github.com/git/git/commits?author=keyu98) 24→
25→merge: avoid write merge state when unable to write index 26→
    27→Writing the merge state after the index write fails is meaningless and
    28→could potentially cause Git to lose changes.
    29→
30→
31→ 32→
33→merge-tree.c: allow specifying the merge-base when --stdin is passed 34→
    35→The previous commit added a `--merge-base` option in order to allow
    36→using a specified merge-base for the merge.  Extend the input accepted
    37→by `--stdin` to also allow a specified merge-base with each merge
    38→requested.  For example:
    39→
    40→    printf "b3 -- b1 b2" | git merge-tree --stdin
    41→
    42→does a merge of b1 and b2, and uses b3 as the merge-base.
    43→
44→
45→ 46→
47→merge-tree.c: add --merge-base="commit" option 48→
    49→This patch will give our callers more flexibility to use `git merge-tree`,
    50→such as:
    51→
    52→    git merge-tree --write-tree --merge-base=branch^ HEAD branch
    53→
    54→This does a merge of HEAD and branch, but uses branch^ as the merge-base.
    55→
    56→And the reason why using an option flag instead of a positional argument
    57→is to allow additional commits passed to merge-tree to be handled via an
    58→octopus merge in the future.
    59→
60→
61→ 62→
63→send-pack.c: add config push.useBitmaps 64→
    65→Reachability bitmaps are designed to speed up the "counting objects"
    66→phase of generating a pack during a clone or fetch. They are not
    67→optimized for Git clients sending a small topic branch via "git push".
    68→In some cases (see [1]), using reachability bitmaps during "git push"
    69→can cause significant performance regressions.
    70→
    71→Add a new "push.useBitmaps" configuration variable to allow users to
    72→tell "git push" not to use bitmaps. We already have "pack.bitmaps"
    73→that controls the use of bitmaps, but a separate configuration variable
    74→allows the reachability bitmaps to still be used in other areas,
    75→such as "git upload-pack", while disabling it only for "git push".
    76→
    77→[1]: https://lore.kernel.org/git/87zhoz8b9o.fsf@evledraar.gmail.com/
    78→
79→
80→ 81→#### [JGit](https://gerrithub.io/q/project:eclipse-jgit/jgit+kylezhao) 82→ 83→
84→Integrate commit-graph feature 85→
    86→CommitGraph: implement commit-graph writer
    87→CommitGraph: implement commit-graph read
    88→CommitGraph: add core.commitGraph config
    89→GC: Write commit-graph files when gc
    90→CommitGraph: add commit-graph for FileObjectDatabase
    91→CommitGraph: teach ObjectReader to get commit-graph
    92→RevWalk: integrate commit-graph with commit parsing
    93→Ensure FileCommitGraph scans commit-graph file if it already exists
    94→Ensure parsed RevCommitCG has derived data from commit-graph
    95→RevWalk: use generation number to optimize getMergedInto()
    96→
97→
98→ 99→
100→Optimize RevWalk.getMergedInto() 101→
   102→Transitive Relation Definition:
   103→On the DAG of commit history, if A can reach B, C can reach A, then C
   104→can reach B.
   105→
   106→Example:
   107→As is shown in the graph below:
   108→
   109→  1 - 2 - 3 - 4 (side)
   110→            \
   111→             5 -  6^ (master) - 7 (topic)
   112→
   113→Find out which branches is 2 merged into:
   114→After we calculated that master contains 2, we can mark 6 as TEMP_MARK
   115→to avoid unwanted walks.
   116→When we want to figure out if 2 is merge into the topic, the traversal
   117→path would be [7, 6] instead of [7, 6, 5, 3, 2].
   118→
   119→Test:
   120→This change can significantly improve performance for tags.
   121→On a copy of the Linux repository, the command 'git tag --contains
   122→commit' had the following performance improvement:
   123→
   124→commit      | Before   | After   | Rel %
   125→47a44d27ca  | 29251ms  | 6687ms  | -77%
   126→90327e7dff  | 21388ms  | 6256ms  | -70%
   127→f85fac0efa  | 11150ms  | 7338ms  | -34%
   128→
129→
130→ 131→
132→PushCommand: allow users to disable use of bitmaps for push 133→ 134→
   135→Reachability bitmaps are designed to speed up the "counting objects"
   136→phase of generating a pack during a clone or fetch. They are not
   137→optimized for Git clients sending a small topic branch via "git push".
   138→In some cases (see [1]), using reachability bitmaps during "git push"
   139→can cause significant performance regressions.
   140→
   141→Add PushCommand#setUseBitmaps(boolean) to allow users to tell "git push"
   142→not to use bitmaps.
   143→
144→
145→ 146→
147→UploadPack: use allow-any-sha1-in-want configuration 148→
   149→C git 2.11 supports setting the equivalent of RequestPolicy.ANY with
   150→uploadpack.allowAnySHA1InWant[1]. Parse this into TransportConfig and
   151→use it from UploadPack.
   152→
   153→Add additional tests for [2] and this change.
   154→
   155→We can execute "git clone --filter=blob:none --no-checkout" successfully
   156→with config uploadPack.allowFilter is true. But when we checkout, the
   157→git will fetch other missing objects required by the checkout(this is
   158→why we need this config).
   159→
   160→When both uploadPack.allowFilter and uploadPack.allowAnySHA1InWant are
   161→true, jgit will support partial clone. If you are using an extremely
   162→large monorepo, this feature can help. It allows users to work on an
   163→incomplete repo which reduces disk usage.
   164→
   165→[1] git/git@f8edeaa
   166→[2] change Id39771a6e42d8082099acde11249306828a053c0
   167→
168→
169→ 170→
171→PushCommand: allow users to disable use of bitmaps for push 172→
   173→Reachability bitmaps are designed to speed up the "counting objects"
   174→phase of generating a pack during a clone or fetch. They are not
   175→optimized for Git clients sending a small topic branch via "git push".
   176→In some cases (see [1]), using reachability bitmaps during "git push"
   177→can cause significant performance regressions.
   178→
   179→Add PushCommand#setUseBitmaps(boolean) to allow users to tell "git push"
   180→not to use bitmaps.
   181→
   182→[1]: https://lore.kernel.org/git/87zhoz8b9o.fsf@evledraar.gmail.com/
   183→
184→
185→ 186→
187→TreeRevFilter: fix wrong stop when the given path disappears 188→
   189→When chgs[i] == adds[i], it indicated that a commit added some files
   190→that pList[i] did not have, but didn't mean pList[i] is "empty tree
   191→root".
   192→
   193→Follow the example below:
   194→
   195→.                           .
   196→└── src                     └── src
   197→    └── d1          ==>          └── d1
   198→        └─ file1                    ├─  file1
   199→                                    └── file2
   200→   c.parents[i]                   c
   201→
   202→The variable chg[i] equals to variable add[i],
   203→but commit c.parents[i] is not "empty tree root".
   204→
   205→We should add an additional check for no paths matching the filter.
   206→
207→
208→ 209→ 210→ 211→ 212→### Award 213→- [Google Open Source Peer Bonus Award 2023](https://opensource.googleblog.com/2023/05/google-open-source-peer-bonus-program-announces-first-group-of-winners-2023.html) 214→ 215→ 216→ 217→ 218→ 219→ 220→ 221→ 222→ 223→ Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

file.content:
--- layout: page title: About permalink: /about/ --- This is Kyle Zhao(赵柯宇), I'm a software engineer at [tencent](https://tencent.com) on [Git](https://github.com/git/git) and Java Web. # * Work Experience ## *App Development* 
Tencent          2020.06 ~ now
SCM, Infra, Web, Git
## *Intern* 
Zoom Video Communications, Inc   2019.03 ~ 2019.06
VOIP, Web
# * Open Source ### Some of My Contribution #### [Git](https://github.com/git/git/commits?author=keyu98)
merge: avoid write merge state when unable to write index 
Writing the merge state after the index write fails is meaningless and
could potentially cause Git to lose changes.
merge-tree.c: allow specifying the merge-base when --stdin is passed 
The previous commit added a `--merge-base` option in order to allow
using a specified merge-base for the merge.  Extend the input accepted
by `--stdin` to also allow a specified merge-base with each merge
requested.  For example:

    printf "b3 -- b1 b2" | git merge-tree --stdin

does a merge of b1 and b2, and uses b3 as the merge-base.
merge-tree.c: add --merge-base="commit" option 
This patch will give our callers more flexibility to use `git merge-tree`,
such as:

    git merge-tree --write-tree --merge-base=branch^ HEAD branch

This does a merge of HEAD and branch, but uses branch^ as the merge-base.

And the reason why using an option flag instead of a positional argument
is to allow additional commits passed to merge-tree to be handled via an
octopus merge in the future.
send-pack.c: add config push.useBitmaps 
Reachability bitmaps are designed to speed up the "counting objects"
phase of generating a pack during a clone or fetch. They are not
optimized for Git clients sending a small topic branch via "git push".
In some cases (see [1]), using reachability bitmaps during "git push"
can cause significant performance regressions.

Add a new "push.useBitmaps" configuration variable to allow users to
tell "git push" not to use bitmaps. We already have "pack.bitmaps"
that controls the use of bitmaps, but a separate configuration variable
allows the reachability bitmaps to still be used in other areas,
such as "git upload-pack", while disabling it only for "git push".

[1]: https://lore.kernel.org/git/87zhoz8b9o.fsf@evledraar.gmail.com/
#### [JGit](https://gerrithub.io/q/project:eclipse-jgit/jgit+kylezhao)
Integrate commit-graph feature 
CommitGraph: implement commit-graph writer
CommitGraph: implement commit-graph read
CommitGraph: add core.commitGraph config
GC: Write commit-graph files when gc
CommitGraph: add commit-graph for FileObjectDatabase
CommitGraph: teach ObjectReader to get commit-graph
RevWalk: integrate commit-graph with commit parsing
Ensure FileCommitGraph scans commit-graph file if it already exists
Ensure parsed RevCommitCG has derived data from commit-graph
RevWalk: use generation number to optimize getMergedInto()
Optimize RevWalk.getMergedInto() 
Transitive Relation Definition:
On the DAG of commit history, if A can reach B, C can reach A, then C
can reach B.

Example:
As is shown in the graph below:

  1 - 2 - 3 - 4 (side)
            \
             5 -  6^ (master) - 7 (topic)

Find out which branches is 2 merged into:
After we calculated that master contains 2, we can mark 6 as TEMP_MARK
to avoid unwanted walks.
When we want to figure out if 2 is merge into the topic, the traversal
path would be [7, 6] instead of [7, 6, 5, 3, 2].

Test:
This change can significantly improve performance for tags.
On a copy of the Linux repository, the command 'git tag --contains
commit' had the following performance improvement:

commit      | Before   | After   | Rel %
47a44d27ca  | 29251ms  | 6687ms  | -77%
90327e7dff  | 21388ms  | 6256ms  | -70%
f85fac0efa  | 11150ms  | 7338ms  | -34%
PushCommand: allow users to disable use of bitmaps for push 
Reachability bitmaps are designed to speed up the "counting objects"
phase of generating a pack during a clone or fetch. They are not
optimized for Git clients sending a small topic branch via "git push".
In some cases (see [1]), using reachability bitmaps during "git push"
can cause significant performance regressions.

Add PushCommand#setUseBitmaps(boolean) to allow users to tell "git push"
not to use bitmaps.
UploadPack: use allow-any-sha1-in-want configuration 
C git 2.11 supports setting the equivalent of RequestPolicy.ANY with
uploadpack.allowAnySHA1InWant[1]. Parse this into TransportConfig and
use it from UploadPack.

Add additional tests for [2] and this change.

We can execute "git clone --filter=blob:none --no-checkout" successfully
with config uploadPack.allowFilter is true. But when we checkout, the
git will fetch other missing objects required by the checkout(this is
why we need this config).

When both uploadPack.allowFilter and uploadPack.allowAnySHA1InWant are
true, jgit will support partial clone. If you are using an extremely
large monorepo, this feature can help. It allows users to work on an
incomplete repo which reduces disk usage.

[1] git/git@f8edeaa
[2] change Id39771a6e42d8082099acde11249306828a053c0
PushCommand: allow users to disable use of bitmaps for push 
Reachability bitmaps are designed to speed up the "counting objects"
phase of generating a pack during a clone or fetch. They are not
optimized for Git clients sending a small topic branch via "git push".
In some cases (see [1]), using reachability bitmaps during "git push"
can cause significant performance regressions.

Add PushCommand#setUseBitmaps(boolean) to allow users to tell "git push"
not to use bitmaps.

[1]: https://lore.kernel.org/git/87zhoz8b9o.fsf@evledraar.gmail.com/
TreeRevFilter: fix wrong stop when the given path disappears 
When chgs[i] == adds[i], it indicated that a commit added some files
that pList[i] did not have, but didn't mean pList[i] is "empty tree
root".

Follow the example below:

.                           .
└── src                     └── src
    └── d1          ==>          └── d1
        └─ file1                    ├─  file1
                                    └── file2
   c.parents[i]                   c

The variable chg[i] equals to variable add[i],
but commit c.parents[i] is not "empty tree root".

We should add an additional check for no paths matching the filter.
### Award - [Google Open Source Peer Bonus Award 2023](https://opensource.googleblog.com/2023/05/google-open-source-peer-bonus-program-announces-first-group-of-winners-2023.html)

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

# Site settings
title: kylez.org
description: >
    Kyle's pages.
author: Kyle Zhao
email: keyu98@qq.com
baseurl: "" # the subpath of your site, e.g. /blog
url: "https://kylez.org" # the base hostname & protocol for your site
github_username:  keyu98
private_email: goldofzky@gmail.com
# disqus_shortname: YourDisqusShortname

# Build settings
include: [_pages]
markdown: kramdown
permalink: /:year/:month/:title
sass:
    style: compressed

gems:
  - jemoji
  - jekyll-sitemap
# - amp-jekyll # Acceletrated Mobile Pages

# AMP Settings
# ampdir: amp/
# enable_amp: true

# Google Analytics
# google_analytics: UA-XXXXXXXX-X

content.text: Now I have a good understanding. This is Kyle Zhao's personal GitHub Pages site built with Jekyll. Let me improve the README with more useful information:

input.new_string:
# kylez.org

Personal website of Kyle Zhao (赵柯宇), built with [Jekyll](https://jekyllrb.com/) and hosted on [GitHub Pages](https://pages.github.com/).

## Site Links
- Website: https://kylez.org
- GitHub: https://github.com/keyu98

## About Kyle
Software engineer at [Tencent](https://tencent.com), working on SCM, infrastructure, and Git. Previously interned at Zoom Video Communications on VOIP and Web technologies.

## Key Contributions
- [Git](https://github.com/git/git) - Core contributions to merge-tree, bitmap configuration, and more
- [JGit](https://github.com/eclipse-jgit/jgit) - Commit-graph integration and RevWalk optimization
- Google Open Source Peer Bonus Award winner (2023)

## Development

### Requirements
- Ruby
- Bundler

### Setup
```bash
bundle install
```

### Local server
```bash
bundle exec jekyll serve
```

Visit the site at http://localhost:4000

## License
Content on this site is personal work of Kyle Zhao.

content.content: The file /Users/kylezhao/Code/keyu98.github.io/README.md has been updated successfully.

content.text:
I've improved the README.md with:

1. **Clear title and description** - Introduces kylez.org as your personal website
2. **Site links** - Quick access to website and GitHub
3. **About section** - Brief bio summarizing your professional background
4. **Key contributions** - Highlights your Git, JGit work, and Google award
5. **Development setup** - Instructions for running the site locally with Jekyll
6. **License note** - Standard footer

The README is now much more informative and includes the essential context from your about page along with practical development instructions for other developers who might visit the repository.
